code: @Manual{,   title = {sdp: Stochastic degradation process},   author = {Liangliang Zhuang and Wenhui Wu},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.2.0},   url = {https://liangliangzhuang.github.io/sdp/}, }

title: Stochastic degradation process
text: goal sdp provide engineers practical guidance analyze data using common degradation models: Wiener process, Gamma process, Inverse Gaussian process. degradation process, provide data simulation generation, statistical inference, remaining useful life prognostics.

title: Stochastic degradation process
text: can install development version sdp GitHub :

title: Stochastic degradation process
text: sdp functions fall five main categories: “Simulation” can simulate group degradation models, see sim_dat(). “Inference” contains maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) Bayesian method, see sta_infer(). “Ploting” contains several visualization functions, mainly plotting degradation paths, reliability remaining useful life. See plot_path(), RUL_plot(), Reliability_plot(), Reliability_cowplot(), RUL_3D_density(). “Others” contains useful functions. See cumsub(), acc_stress().

title: Stochastic degradation process
text: Real data analysis Simulation data analysis

title: NASA 锂电池数据 — lithium_battery
text: 该数据是 NASA Ames Prognostics Center Fxcellence (PCoF）对商用锂离子 18650 电池进行充、放电试验获得的一组蓄电池容量变化数据。试验过程中，锂离子在室温下 经历 3 种不同的运行剖面，即充电、放电和测量 EIS。 充电是以恒流模式(CC)进行，在 1.5A 电流下直到电池电压达到4.2V，然后以恒压模式(CV)继续充电直到电流降到 20mA。 放电也以恒流模式进行，放电电流为2A，直到电池电压降低到2.7V。 重复充电和放电将导致蓄电池老化。

title: NASA 锂电池数据 — lithium_battery

title: Remaining Useful Life — plot_path
code: # data simulation (a Wiener linear process with 5 units) dat <- sim_dat(group = 5, t = 1:200, para = c(2,3), process = "Wiener",type = "classical", s = NULL, rel = NULL) # Plot degradation path library(ggplot2) plot_path(dat)  # add ggplot related functions. plot_path(dat) + theme_bw() + theme(panel.grid = element_blank())

text: group number groups products t time. para parameters certain model. process Wiener, Gamma Inverse Gaussian process. type classical default. s stress. rel relationship.

title: Statistical inference — sta_infer
text: function used statistical inference model parameters. methods including maximum likelihood estimator Bayesian inference.

title: Statistical inference — sta_infer
code: sta_infer(   method = "MLE",   process = "Wiener",   type = "classical",   data = NULL,   p = 0.975,   par = c(1, 1),   chains = 1,   warmup = 1000,   iter = 2000,   cores = 1,   s = NULL,   rel = NULL )

title: Statistical inference — sta_infer
text: method time. process Wiener, Gamma Inverse Gaussian process. type classical default. data degradation data. p default `p=0.975`. par initial parameter. chains default `chains = 1` warmup default `warmup = 1000`. iter default `iter= 2000`. cores cores = 1, s stress. rel relationship.

title: Statistical inference — sta_infer
text: Returns data frame method MLE, returns stan raw results method Bayes.

title: Statistical inference — sta_infer
code: dat <- sim_dat(group = 5, t = 1:200, para = c(2,3), process = "Wiener",type = "classical", s = NULL, rel = NULL) # MLE mle_fit = sta_infer(method = "MLE", process = "Wiener", type = "classical", data = dat) mle_fit #>         low   mean     up #> [1,] 1.8356 2.0198 2.2041 #> [2,] 2.8344 2.9646 3.0949 # Bayes library(rstan) #> Loading required package: StanHeaders #> rstan (Version 2.21.8, GitRev: 2e1f913d3ca3) #> For execution on a local, multicore CPU with excess RAM we recommend calling #> options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()). #> To avoid recompilation of unchanged Stan programs, we recommend calling #> rstan_options(auto_write = TRUE) rstan_options(auto_write = TRUE) options(mc.cores = parallel::detectCores()) bayes_fit = sta_infer(method = "Bayes", process = "Wiener", type = "classical", data = dat) bayes_fit$summary #>      2.5%   mean  97.5% #> mu 1.8460 2.0215 2.2062 #> w  2.8357 2.9670 3.1158 print(bayes_fit$summary, probs = c(0.025,0.5,0.975),pars = c("mu","w")) #>      2.5%   mean  97.5% #> mu 1.8460 2.0215 2.2062 #> w  2.8357 2.9670 3.1158 plot(bayes_fit$stan_re) #> ci_level: 0.8 (80% intervals) #> outer_level: 0.95 (95% intervals)  # traceplot(bayes_fit$stan_re,pars = c("mu","w"), #            inc_warmup = TRUE,nrow = 1) + #    theme(legend.position = "top")
